set_logger.py

This module, set_logger.py, is responsible for setting up the logging configuration for the application.

It provides functions to initialize a logger with a specific name, set the logging level, and specify the format of the log messages.

This allows for consistent logging practices across the application, making it easier to debug issues and track application flow.

class set_logger.ColoredDetailedScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler designed for outputting detailed log messages to the screen, including severity level, module name, function name, and line number, all with appropriate color coding for enhanced readability. This handler is suitable for applications requiring detailed context in logs, particularly useful for debugging and monitoring.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.

class set_logger.ColoredPrinterScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler for outputting log messages as plain text with severity level-based color coding to the screen. This handler is optimized for simplicity and visual differentiation of log messages, making it suitable for quick debugging tasks where minimal contextual information is required.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.

class set_logger.DetailedFileHandler(filename, mode='a', encoding=None, delay=False)[source]

Bases: FileHandler

A file-based logging handler that records detailed log messages, including severity level, module name, function name, and line number. This handler is tailored for persistent logging to a file, where detailed contextual information is essential for post-mortem analysis and archiving purposes.

Inherits from logging.FileHandler.

class set_logger.DetailedScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler that outputs detailed log messages to the screen without color coding. It includes information such as severity level, module name, function name, and line number, providing a comprehensive context for each log entry. This handler is ideal for environments where color coding is not supported or required.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.

class set_logger.Filter_name(allowed: str | list | None = None)[source]

Bases: Filter

A logging filter that will determine if a log record should be processed based on which logger emitted the record. This filter is used to separate log records based on the logger name, allowing for different handling of log records based on their source. Useful to attach it to a handler

name

The name of the logger to filter by. If the logger name matches this value, the log record will be processed.

Type:

str

filter(record: LogRecord) → bool[source]

Determines if the log record should be processed based on the logger name.

Parameters:

record (logging.LogRecord) – The log record to process.

Returns:

True if the log record should be processed, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

class set_logger.Formatters[source]

Bases: object

Provides static methods for creating various logging.Formatter objects. This class acts as a namespace and is not intended to be instantiated. It encapsulates formatter definitions for ease of use and consistency across different logging handlers.

static colored_detailed_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Generates a formatter that provides detailed logging information, including log level, logger name, module name, function name, and line number, all colored based on the severity level. Ideal for in-depth debugging where context is crucial.

Returns:

An instance configured for detailed, colored log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static colored_print_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Creates a formatter for logging messages as plain text with color coding according to the severity level. It simplifies output while retaining visual distinction of log severity for quick scanning.

Returns:

An instance configured for plain text, colored log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static colored_simple_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Creates a formatter for logging with minimal information, adding color coding according to the severity level. Suitable for concise and visually distinguishable log messages.

Returns:

An instance configured for simple, colored log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static detailed_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Creates a formatter for logging detailed messages without color coding. Includes log level, module name, function name, and line number, providing a comprehensive context for each log message.

Returns:

An instance configured for detailed log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static json_formatter(structured=False) → Formatter[source]

Creates a formatter for logging messages as json objects. This formatter is suitable for persistent logging to a file, where structured data is required for further processing.

Returns:

An instance configured for json log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static pretty_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Produces a formatter that enhances log readability by using delimiters and newlines, along with color coding by severity level. Designed to make critical log messages stand out visually in busy logs.

Returns:

An instance configured for visually enhanced log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static print_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Generates a formatter for logging messages as plain text. This formatter is intended for simple output scenarios where only the message content is of interest, without any additional log metadata.

Returns:

An instance configured for plain text log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

static simple_formatter() → Formatter[source]

Creates a formatter for simple logging. Formats log messages to include the log level and the message.

Returns:

An instance configured for simple log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

class set_logger.JsonFormatter(structured: bool = False)[source]

Bases: Formatter

Creates a formatter for logging messages as json

Returns:

An instance configured for json log messages.

Return type:

logging.Formatter

format(record: LogRecord) → str[source]

Format the specified record as text.

The record’s attribute dictionary is used as the operand to a string formatting operation which yields the returned string. Before formatting the dictionary, a couple of preparatory steps are carried out. The message attribute of the record is computed using LogRecord.getMessage(). If the formatting string uses the time (as determined by a call to usesTime(), formatTime() is called to format the event time. If there is exception information, it is formatted using formatException() and appended to the message.

class set_logger.PersistentLogHandler(filename, mode='a', encoding=None, delay=False)[source]

Bases: FileHandler

A file-based logging handler that records log messages as plain text. This handler is suitable for persistent logging to a file, where all data in the log message can be stored for future reference. The log messages are formatted as json objects for easy parsing.

Inherits from logging.FileHandler.

class set_logger.PersistentLogHandlerStructured(filename, mode='a', encoding=None, delay=False)[source]

Bases: FileHandler

A file-based logging handler that records log messages as plain text. This handler is suitable for persistent logging to a file, where all data in the log message can be stored for future reference. The log messages are formatted as json objects for easy parsing.

Inherits from logging.FileHandler.

class set_logger.PrettyScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler that formats log messages for display on the screen with colors and delimiters for enhanced readability. It uses a custom

format that includes the log level, logger name, function name, line number, and the log message itself.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.

class set_logger.PrinterScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler that outputs log messages as plain text to the screen, without any color coding or additional contextual information. Designed for the most straightforward logging needs, this handler is useful for applications where logs are intended to be minimal and unobtrusive.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.

class set_logger.SimpleScreenHandler[source]

Bases: StreamHandler

A logging handler designed for simple, uncolored output to the screen. Suitable for most applications where minimal log information is sufficient. Formats log messages to include only the log level and the message itself.

Inherits from logging.StreamHandler.
